biography: Aparna Balamurali is an Indian actress and playback singer, who primarily works in Malayalam and Tamil films. She is the recipient of a National Film Award and a Filmfare Award South. Aparna is known for her roles in the films Maheshinte Prathikaaram (2016), Sunday Holiday (2017), Soorarai Pottru (2020), and Kishkindha Kaandam (2024), winning the National Film Award for Best Actress for Soorarai Pottru. In 2025, Aparna was placed by Forbes Asia in their 30 Under 30 list.

As a pediatric neurosurgeon, Dr. Hegde's clinical expertise encompasses a wide range of surgical procedures and medical management strategies for neurological conditions affecting children. For spina bifida, she would likely be skilled in performing closure of the neural tube defect, aiming to protect the spinal cord and prevent further neurological damage. In cases of hydrocephalus, she would likely be experienced in placing ventriculoperitoneal shunts (VP shunts) to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid from the brain, relieving pressure and preventing further neurological complications. She would also likely be proficient in endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV), a minimally invasive procedure that creates an alternative pathway for cerebrospinal fluid flow, often avoiding the need for a shunt.

She would likely be skilled in performing craniotomies to access the brain and remove tumors, employing microsurgical techniques to minimize damage to surrounding brain tissue. She would also be familiar with newer techniques such as stereotactic radiosurgery, which uses focused radiation to target tumors that are difficult to access surgically.

Another key area of expertise would be the surgical management of epilepsy in children. This would involve identifying the seizure focus in the brain and performing surgical resections to remove the affected tissue. She would likely work closely with pediatric neurologists to determine the suitability of surgery for each patient and to plan the surgical approach. She would also be familiar with other surgical techniques for epilepsy, such as vagus nerve stimulation (VNS), which involves implanting a device that stimulates the vagus nerve to reduce seizure frequency.

Furthermore, Dr. Hegde would be proficient in treating traumatic brain injuries in children. This would involve managing intracranial pressure, removing blood clots, and repairing skull fractures.
